posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When loading pistol rounds does anyone else just scoop whatever powder you've got with each primed case and press a bullet in? Also, I've had great luck filling magnum rifle cases (like .300 win mag) with cheap pistol powder. Since pistols are tinier, the powder is tiny...but so is the tiny amount. That's 3 tinies. If you put tiny powder made for tiny guns in a big case made for big guns, it balances out. I've had really good results eyeballing powder amounts into cases with this understanding. With .300wm, for example, I can get a whole range of bullets to fly from 2500fps to 3900fps just by eyeballing and adjusting the powder level. All my loads shoot minute of whitetail at 30 yards, and that's all I'll ever need. If I wanted to try to shoot a deer further away I'd just bring more ammo (that I was able to reload like 3 times faster than those fudd manuals, btw).

Reloading is super easy if you just think about how things work instead of trying to read and follow 10 billion fucking instructions and lawyer warnings which I don't have time for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57121956
its effect on accuracy is due to its effect on the point in the barrel's harmonic movement the bullet leaves the muzzle. Barrels whip around a little when firing, like a tuning fork, generally tracing a figure 8, and accuracy means making the bullet leave the barrel at the same point on that figure 8 each time. The speed of the shockwave moving through the steel of the barrel is roughly 20x the speed of sound in the air, and it traverses the barrel up and back down it ~5 times before the bullet leaves the barrel, squeezing the bullet a little as it passes it. I've seen stuff suggesting you want the bullet to leave the barrel when the shockwave is at one end of the barrel or the other. If the barrel and its mounting were molecularly perfectly square with each other, you wouldn't get any lateral movement of the barrel from this shockwave, but machining methods are never perfect.

I haven't done this because I don't care enough, but you'd want to get a lot of brass from one manufacturer, gauge the neck thickness on all of them and discard any outliers, then anneal all the necks at a given temperature to give them all the same neck tension. Then you can start working to find your most accurate load for that rifle, redoing the annealing process every time you load a given case. If you're chasing accuracy that much, then you'd also be weighing your brass and discarding any outliers, to make sure they have as close as possible internal volume to each other, so that perfectly identical charges result in identical pressures and thus velocities, to make the bullet leave the muzzle at a repeatable point in the barrel flex.

At the moment?

Inside China proper they have a decent air defense network. B-2s, F-35s and F-22s are probably the only aircraft that could get inside and survive. Most strikes inside China would involve cruise missiles with fleeting incursions by the above supported by electronic attack aircraft.

Outside China, eh. They have a lot of ballistic missiles and may be able to strike static targets in Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Vietnam and Guam depending on the targets, missiles used and air defense available. Progress is being made on air defense in the pacific so an attack on Guam might be possible now and impossible in a few years. The location of air defense ships would be a big unknowable factor since SM-3/SM-6 is capable of defeating massed ballistic missile attacks but only in a relatively small area around the ship. Taiwan will absolutely get cratered no matter what, since the Chinese have enough missiles to overwhelm any defense there.

Ships, the consensus seems to be that they're roughly equivalent to US back in ~2008 when it comes to surface attack. They have harpoon equivalents and everything necessary to go up against a US ship. They'd probably get fucked outside of the first island chain trying to go up against a USN DDG but inside they have a chance. Chinese damage control is an unknown factor, training is an unknown factor.

Chinese subs are known to be absolute shit but they have diesel electric and nuclear ones. They may be able to impact shipping. Chinese ASW I'm not too familiar with but efforts do seem to be there and most Chinese surface combatants are probably capable of putting up a decent ASW screen.

Ground forces? No idea.

I think that's the overall issue Russia is facing right now. There really, really seems to be a lot of unironic coping and wishful thinking fueling their strategy at this point, more so than at any point in the first 8ish months. Not a good sign for their prospects.

>Hannibal crosses the Alps in 218 BC
>Romans tackle him directly and get BTFO at battles of Trebia and Tresimene
>Fabius adopts a strategy of avoiding direct confrontation and slowly bleeding the Carthaginians out while cutting them off from support
>Romans get pissed off at this approach and remove Fabius from command
>assemble biggest army in their history and attack Hannibal directly again
>Rome suffers the biggest defeat in their history at Cannae
>return to Fabian strategy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57097624
Depends. Do you plan on being in a burning building or vehicle? If so then polyester under armour style shirts aren't a good idea as a base (unless you like having a shirt melt to your torso, getting a massive infection, and spending a month in a burn unit living in an oxygen tent having your gooch skin grafted to your chest). If you're just gonna larp any generic polyester t-shirt should do as long as you've got someone competent doing the needle work.

Don't like melting? Well then it's got to be nomex. Oh wait you're gonna melt in the sun because fuck is everything made out of nomex hot to wear in the summer. That being said this is the most "realistic" option for a base shirt (since real combat shirts are going to be at least melt and drip resistant). IIRC some of the fuelers at battalion had the Massif Cool Knit shirts issued and they were ok. Fort Chaffee is 110f in the summer so wearing clothes at all is too hot.

Well what about cotton? Cotton is fine...Except if you plan on being in an area which may be rainy and wet and 50f or less? Cotton based shirts aren't your friend. When cotton gets wet it loses its heat retention properties and is a one way ticket to hypothermia. That being said cheap subdued colored cotton shirts from Duke or other companies are common and cheap. Every milsurp store carries them and you can get a ton of them for not much.

There is smart wool but I don't recommend that for any hot climate because you know wool is wool. For a winter weight uniform they'd be great. It's just fucking expensive.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57106577
General purpose bugout bag for shtf

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57106658
60L ought to do it. You'll want:
> calorie-dense food
> rope
> small flashlight
> glow sticks
> lighters
> zip ties
> knife
> toothbrush
> compass
> IFAK
> emergency blanket
> sewing kit
> bandana
> map of local area
> fire-starter
> cloths pins
> LifeStraw
> braided cable
> propane stove
> trail marker tape
> spork multi-tool
> multi-tool
> automatic fishing reel
> spices
> pocket saw
> light cookware
> folding shovel
> ballpoint pen
> antiseptic
> antibiotics
> iodine water purification tablets
> multivitamin/mineral (not necessary if you're only out there for 2-3 days, but good to have, especially if you get lost or stuck.)
> .22lr pistol
> ammo
> slingshot
> poncho/shelter
> changes of clothes (socks in particular)
It sounds like a lot, but it can easily pack into a 60L or smaller bag.

>>57109469
How much do you want to spend? I really like the Steiner military and marine series for the money, especially if you find a lightly used pair or on sale. The 7x50 are probably the best balance of image and balance, the 8x30s which are good all-arounders since they're lighter and smaller. Also have a set of M24 7x28 by L3 which fit in a large pocket, but they have laser filters that distort color and a reticle that's pretty much useless. You can get a the Fuji version w/o that but they'll cost more.
This stuff applies to all brands though, might be best to just grab a cheap mid-magnification pair and consider what you like/dislike about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57106758
only cause you posted...
in your kit you have 3 water filtration tools.
>bandana
>lifestraw
>iodine tabs

you need 1, maybe 2.

think about it, 1st layer is the bandana. itll filter most debris. believe it or not, you can drink more water than you think.
2nd, iodine.
you're on the move. chug your water you got then fill it up through the bandana, drop a tab, keep moving.
3rd, life straw. what's the scenario you have time to use that thing? it's an emergency, i get that but it's 8in long. do you have the space and weight for the long march? you do you but there's safe and there's over kill.
in the SW i'd maybe get it since the lack of water and abundance of cattle but elsewhere? you've already made space for the fishing pole so water must be plentiful.

I'd first say drop the pole for a jar of peanut butter but 2nd is drop the life straw. you'll be fine with iodine.
i'd also say the fire starter should be a bic. little effort for hundreds of lights.
otherwise pretty solid.
a decent knife can be a pocket saw too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57111633
No pole -- automatic fishing reel, yo-yo style. A hell of a lot smaller.
Peanut butter is a great idea. Also famine food like Twix Peanut Butter. (AFAIK, that's the candy bar with the most calories per ounce.)
I got some bic lighters in there alongside the fire starter.
You're right about the LifeStraw. You probably don't need it unless you plan on staying out for a really long time.
One thing I forgot to add to the list is a solar panel to USB charger. Could use it to recharge the flashlight, and you can bring a lightweight Kindle e-reader with you to kill some of the boredom. Very small weight/space penalty for both.

>>57113495
Depends what you mean by "primary" here. I know that the G3 and it's derivatives form a sort of separate family of their own (which I personally assert can be further traced back to the StG 44 as the "patriarch" of this family, but that's another argument), but I'm not so sure they can be considered a "primary platform" if you're referring to pure market relevance in the present day. I don't really know of many countries that still use G3/CETME derivatives today other than Turkey.
The AR-18 and it's derivatives are somewhat popular as a third option, usually in the form of a clone produced by a poorer country. In fact, I don't recall if any nation adopted the actual AR-18 itself, I think they all just made knockoffs that were slightly different. I believe Mexico's current service rifle is based off the AR-18, despite it's outer appearance looking more like a G36 (which itself is sort of based off the AR-18 anyway, so whatever).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57113495
Realistically, you have longstroke pistol (arguably M1 Garand/AK derived), shortstroke piston (AR18 derived), direct impingement (AR10/ar15 derived), and roller locked (STG 45/HK derived).
Roller delayed is pretty much just HK shit, current production longstrokes at this point are just AKs and m1s, DI is pretty much just AR15s and AR10s, and shortstroke piston is everything else. All the current development worth talking about is shortstroke.

Depending on what you mean by primary, there's shit like straight blowback and long recoil, but those aren't really made with normal rifle calibers in mind. You start getting into really niche shit after that.

https://www.fieldandstream.com/blasts-from-past-american-gun-company-12-gauge-shotgun/
https://www.gunvaluesboard.com/american-gun-company-new-york-sxs-12-gage-hammer-gun-30483018.html

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57120720
a match barrel is supposed to be more accurate than a standard barrel, and it is usually heavier. you would want it, as the name implies, for precision shooting in a shooting match.
It also really depends on what rifle or pistol you are using whether it is worth the additional cost and weight.
match barrels are often not chrome lined, because chrome lining can affect the accuracy of the barrel and even though modern techniques can eliminate that to a greater or lesser extent, the marrket (fuddlore) says don't chrome line match barrels, so people don't. They are often made from stainless steel to compensate for this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57120001
>Is modern ammo fine? Can I use any ammo?
Use lead shot only. Some swear it's fine to shoot steel in old guns but I would not want to shoot steel out of that thing; even the English experience ringing (expanding a small section of your barrel) in some of their old guns when shooting steel shot. Clay/target ammo (lead) and small game ammo (lead) would probably be fine but I don't have enough experience to say for sure anything bigger would be fine. Wouldn't shoot slugs (maybe even buck?) through it as IIRC one barrel on a side by side tends to be choked, though which, I forget. Make sure that this gun has a 2 3/4" chamber. Do NOT fucking shoot 3" 12ga out of it. DO NOT. It appears to be 2 3/4" and not the odd 2 1/2". https://www.fieldandstream.com/blasts-from-past-american-gun-company-12-gauge-shotgun/
>What should I know before using it?
Is old. Do not shoot pissin' hot shit through it like turkey ammo.
>was made in the 40s
maybe older, see link.
>I can't find a date or serial number if it even has one.
Probably doesn't! Old shotguns don't tend to have them at all.

posts.name: KM
posts.com:
>>57123916
>I take that to mean it was rated to stop musket fire.
It varies a bit, but it could mean muskets. Acceptance testing for all breastplates delivered to the Swedish army in the late 17th century for example was a shot from the standard issue infantry musket (a 20mm lead ball sitting on top of 20g, ca 308 grains, of blackpowder) at twenty paces.

As for equipping everyone with them, well, they're heavy, expensive, and available manufacturing capacity may not be sufficient to supply even just your cavalry. With the state of healthcare back then limb shots may have been a greater percentage of the people killed, and so the increase in survivability from torso protection may not have been as great even if such hits were almost certain death. (Even more so if we look at total casualties and not just people shot with small arms fire while standing there in the line.)

>>57123993

Antique dealers and auctions.

>>57125191
>decreasing weight via construction
While fair you have to remember that the most mass comes from the fuel or batteries rather than the airframe and the payload, depending on what the payload is. Increasing the energy density and efficiency at which you extract power from it to turn it in to electricity would optimize the size and range of the aircraft. ICEs and turbines are fairly efficient at using energy dense fuels, and they dont need to convert electricity back in to kinetic energy for the rotor, but their scaling sucks. So with fuel cells you could in theory get all of the advantages of battery powered drones, that is compactness and cheap construction, since the only moving parts are the engines and servos for control surfaces which are cheap as fuck. And you get some advantages of energy dense fuel which increases the range within the existing light drone aircraft framework, which again simplifies the problem because you dont need to reinvent the wheel too much.
When it comes to such drones they would ideally be expendable per the recent nato report about the war. So ideally you would not want some meme expensive carbon fiber composites that you cant even source most of the time, let alone build. At least thats my reasoning behind fuel cells as a power source. The only other little problem is that they are also inefficient as fuck and have low power production per area which means that if you want 12 v prepare to stack those motherfuckers like the Eiffel tower.

>>57124235
- destruction of GPS satellites
- specialised jamming (e.g. instead of just blasting noise, send fake gps information or fake video packets and rc packets) - easier said than done, probably not something russia could do without chinese help
- laser CIWS with passive radio targeting
- jamming with other drones - a lot of the issue with sending lots of radio noise at a drone is that you are on the ground in a forest and its up in the air. you could get much better delivery of signal in direct LOS and with matched antenna polarity.
- more powerful jamming equipment - doesnt need to be huge but needs way more power than a few kW to be effective at range. You could have a jamming truck running a serious jammer that might actually fry electronics

posts.com: how do we counter birds?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Very simplified paint diagram to help explain.

As an example, if you look at the vertically polarised rc & video link, if some russian on the ground is not pointing their very directional antenna straight at the drone, they will miss, and even if they do get it straight at it, the jamming signal is going to be significantly horizontally polarised. In simpler terms, the antenna on the drone will only see electrons that move up and down, and if the jamming signal is at a big angle to that, then all the side to side electron movement from the jamming signal doesnt actually do anything, only a small vertical component does. Its a cosine relationship. the GPS antenna is directional so its harder to jam in that sense, but its also recieving much lower power signals from space, so less noise is needed to jam it. Airborne jamming would be the best way to do low power highly portable jamming. Anything from the ground needs to be higher power, and designed smarter.

The more interesting question is just how good is proper military radio stuff; if this is a product you can buy off the shelf.

>>57124490
for example, there is celestial navigation on some cruise missiles. No gps required for long distance travel.

Its also almost impossible to jam low bandwidth radio links. If the military wants to send targeting information to a drone, it would be very hard to stop that since it could be broadcast spread spectrum and repeatedly. However something like video is much easier to jam because there's so much data that you need to push thru the link that its less robust to noise and harder to hide in background radiation from being detected, characterised and countered

>the drone arms race hasnt really begun
idk about that. Current widespread military drones:
- Large aircraft that do typical aircraft missions like close air support and live imaging
- Guided munitions (big and small, e.g. switchblade)
- Tiny squad level surveillance e.g. Black Hornet Nano

The black hornet nano and switchblade are pretty much the perfect squad level drones. There's nothing that comes close to them that you could hack together from chinese parts. Larger drones are widely developed and in use by militaries all over the world.

What's happening in this war in ukraine will give lots of information to militaries about these things, but realistically everything you see is consumer tech thats far behind what militaries have right now.

Have you ever wondered just how moronic the Star Destroyers really are?
Huge and MASSIVE (requiring a mountain of resources for construction), equipped with a shitton of crew (all processes are done manually without automation), but at the same time as vulnerable as possible and can be destroyed with one(!) single successful hit on the command bridge (exposed to literally every enemy gun). The loss of one such ship should be a blow to both the economy and demography (each such vessel, in addition to the main crew, also has at its disposal a considerable army force for ground battles). And it's good if the crew consists of clones, whom no one will mourn except for extras, but if ordinary people serve on the ship - one shot at the command bridge and several tens of thousands of families will be left without a father.
But the most foolish thing about them is the gun battery. According to the scenario excuses, the triangular shape of the ship should contribute to the concentration of fire in the forward hemisphere. But in reality, the battery of the main caliber is located in such a way that it can fire all(!) guns either up or to the sides. In order to concentrate all the fire ahead of the ship, the vessel must be tilted bow down so that the gun turrets do not overlap the view of one another. In a non-retarded implementation of the "all fire in the forward hemisphere" concept, the gun batteries should have been located directly on the sides of the ship.

>>57113475
>shartwars is retarded
welcome to middle school

>Vessel must be tilted bow down to fire all guns at target
A WW2 warship usually can't fire all of its main guns at a target unless the target is in the starboard or port quadrant. Even crazier several tended to have more firepower int he rear quadrant than forward, so you had the least firepower in pursuit.

As for "Children of a Dead Earth" spacecraft it it is armor efficient to have your weapons focused at the sharpest armor angle and smallest cross-section. I'm in favor of forward firepower and a single arc of firepower which ends up with a pyramid shape, kind of like half a star destroyer cut down the middle. With the single protected firepower arc you have maximum armor and can thrust in any direction while rolling your armor/weapon arc towards the enemy. It is ideally effective against a single threat direction, but there's no better answer because all-round armor is inefficient and being flanked is bad. You want nuclear flash and fragmentation protection on your soft underbelly for missiles that explode nearby.

Also unarmored and "flash resistant" propellant drop-tanks are good choices to reduce both armor and structure mass. I still add a small auxiliary armored fueltank near the rocket engine pods so there's some propellant available if all of my external tanks are perforated.

Finally, use propellant tankers and keep them out of direct combat. They're there to keep your combat ships topped off and to rescue and refuel your combat ships that have survived combat.

Arsenal ships with drones and longer range missiles are also important to screen for the tankers and to support the armored combat ship's decisive battle. Two-stage cruise missiles and cruise drones (you can also MIRV your missiles and drones onto a single cruise rocket) can fleet with your combat ships, which is kind of neat how you can have hundreds of missiles and drones as long range and long-term loitering munitions.

To try and answer the whole droid thing, as far as I can tell it's a poorly translated holdover from Dune, which George used as the basis of Star Wars.
You see, in Dune, they had this thing called the Butlerian Jihad where they wiped out all machines, and then banned any kind of thinking machine under penalty of death. So in Dune, there are no computers or simple calculators, let alone robots anymore. They have specially-engineered autistics to act as living computers and slavery and serfdom.
With Star Wars, George wanted robots. So he put robots into the setting. As far as justifying this while maintaining the atmosphere of Dune, there's a few explanations/copes to explain why nothing is automated and why droids have to be supplemented with slave labor.
For the former, they say that droids aren't as "creative" as organics, and are thus more predictable. The idea is that a droid gunner or starfighter will have noticeable patterns to it's attacks or firing patterns that will render it easily countered with a little organic trickery. But there are some very effective droid fighters and soldiers in lore, so it's a matter of "what does George feel like doing now?"
For the latter, everyone is racist to droids. Everyone hates them, to the point that they're able to feel pain and be tortured. There's zero reason to make a sentient robot able to suffer unless you hate it. I believe the idea was that in the distant past, something similar to the Butlerian Jihad happened in response to a machine uprising. After putting the robots in their place, they were then made to pay for their sins and the sins of their forebears with slavery, torture, and general derision and persecution. It goes deep enough that every single droid is programmed to believe in a made-up robot god they call "the Maker", to keep them docile and subservient to organics.
Yes, this is all very autistic and the logic is very touch and go at best.

I have to say that virtually all science fiction has dumb and "unrealistic" battles, often with tactics considerably less effective and more primitive than any used in real life militaries today, BECAUSE real life warfare today is inherently boring.

There is a certain cinematic romance to the swordfight, the pistol duel, the frigate broadside, the depth charge submarine stalking, the wheeling dogfights of prop fighters trying to machinegun each other, the siege and breach, and there's basically nothing that personal or interesting that happens on a battlefield today.

And that's not to say the older battles were that romantic in reality either - 80% of all fatalities for the last millennium or so were caused by some asshole with a cannon shooting vaguely in the direction of some asshole standing around, causing two people who never met or even saw each other to kill each other, and that's not accounting for the way that every war seemed to involve half of both armies dying of dysentery or malaria before they ever got within 100 miles of each other - but even the "romantic" trappings around the periphery are essentially gone now.

>>57114876
>If you want to invade a planet, then build specialized “amphib” ships with troop carriers and tactical air support craft for that

you've got to understand the design lineage of the star destroyer, then it makes more sense. The Star Destroyer concept evolved from the Acclamator Class assault ship, which was basically a large and heavily armed landing ship. It could land troops and then give them heavy fire support. Some variants replaced their troop and heavy equipment transport capacity in order to carry aircraft as as a sort of escort carrier.

The Venator class, the first true Star Destroyer, was a larger ship which could fulfill the role of both lander and carrier. Because of its considerably larger size, it had space for a heavier armament to provide even better orbital bombardment capability.

Neither of these craft were intended to be front line fleet combatants, however due to the sudden start of the Clone War, the Republic was critically low on capital ships. Their only large ships were a number of mothballed and outdated dreadnoughts, the Acclamator class, and the Venator class. So the Republic forced them into the role of cruisers and battleships.

As the war went on, the Republic opted to keep building multi purpose ships since they didn't have enough shipyards to build dedicated carriers and battleships at a fast enough rate to meet demand. The Victory and the Imperator class are the result of this.

By the end of the Clone Wars, the Republic (and soon Imperial) navy's entire doctrine revolved around star destroyers. They also had no reason to completely reinvent their fleet since they had no real rivals. So instead they just adopted an improved version of the Imperator, the Imperial class as their main capital ship and stuck with it.

While we're on this subject, it's a little funny that this was the original intention for Palpatine when A New Hope was written. He was originally not going to be a Sith lord or even a force sensitive, but instead was portrayed as a weak and generally confused old man being used as a puppet by the Imperial MIC (I believe the direct inspirations were Nixon and Carter). That was the significance of all those dudes meeting up with Tarkin and Vader on the Death Star, as of the original draft of the canon these guys were the oligarchy running the Empire from behind the curtain, the shadow government, the deep state, what have you. Blowing up the Death Star was cutting off the head of the snake, killing their entire shadow government in one fell swoop. After it was clear that people actually wanted more of these movies and it wasn't a flop like every single critic of the time had been saying before it released, the mostly behind the scenes lore had to be rewritten so that more movies actually made sense.
Wasn't the first lore rewrite either, before the prequels came out it was often alluded to that the Empire wasn't a successor state of the Republic but that they were separate governments and had fought a war against each other years ago, and the Empire conquered the Republic. A lot of statements thrown out about admirals serving for over 50 years in the Imperial Navy were later retconned to mean they had previously served in the Republic Navy during the Clone Wars. This isn't even getting into the stranger shit like what the Clone Wars were said to be before the prequels.

for the record I dont really like star wars and agree with you that it's shit writing, however the rule of 2s actually makes some sense in context. The sith are all about power, not just for the individual but for the sith as an idea. The rule of twos is about culling weakness and making sure the most power evil space wizard is in charge. It's an apprenticeship in a very literal sense, the point is for the student to replace the master if the master dies or becomes weak or complacent. If the student challenges and is not yet powerful enough to kill his master he dies and is replaced, if he is powerful or cunning or vicious enough to kill his master and the master does not see it coming or is unable to stop it then he has become weak and for the good of the sith he dies and is replaced. The Student Exists in awe and terror of the master and the master exists in a constant need to be faster, better stronger and more cunning than his student. If the student is in a position where he can overpower or entrap or outmaneuver the master then the master is not longer better than him at evil space wizarding and needs to go and the student *deserves* to replace him because he has surpassed him.

It's all about darwinian fitness and making sure that the sith do not become soft and useless like the jedi, but rather stay hungry alert and vicious at all times.

posts.sub: As Its Defense Industry Teeters on Collapse, JAPAN Increases Profit Margin Allowance
posts.com:
Japanese Defense Minister Hamada Yasukazu has announced a new policy of increasing profit margins of the nation’s defense contractors to a maximum of 15 percent.

Speaking at the Budget Committee of the House of Representatives on January 30, Hamada said the Ministry of Defense in Tokyo will introduce a new profit margin calculation method in order for the nation’s defense companies to secure an **operating profit ratio of up to 10 percent. On top of this, he said the ministry will add up to 5 percent to account for fluctuations in procurement costs.** This new policy will be implemented from fiscal year April 2023.

“Domestic industry is defense capability itself, and there is an urgent need to strengthen its foundation,” Hamada said in the Diet.

His announcement came as the country’s defense manufacturers continue to struggle to turn a profit and as the administration of Prime Minister Kishida Fumio pledges to fundamentally reinforce Japan’s defense capabilities.


More than 100 domestic companies have withdrawn from the defense business in the past 20 years, mainly due to low profitability. Notably, in 2021 Mitsui E&S withdrew from naval and government shipbuilding operations, selling the division to Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI).

A year earlier, Japan’s major chemical producer, Daicel, decided to pull out of the production of emergency ejection systems for aircraft pilots. In 2018, the country’s top construction equipment maker Komatsu stopped developing new models of its Light Armored Vehicle (LAV) for the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force (JGSDF), citing slim profit margins.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
According to the Ministry of Finance, the operating profit margin for defense equipment is 7.07 percent as of fiscal year 2020. However, this profit margin is only an assumption at the time of the contract. **The actual profit margin is said to be 2-3 percent on average,** due to soaring material costs after receiving orders as well as other unexpected cost increases.

Given the lack of financial incentives involved, defense equipment accounts for a small portion of many of Japanese defense contractors’ overall operations. Even Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Japan’s largest defense company, generates only 10 percent of its revenue from defense-related operations.

To expand overseas sales channels for defense equipment and support defense companies, the Japanese government is now considering revising the guidelines in the so-called Three Principles of Transfer of Defense Equipment and Technology. Under current guidelines, finished products that can be exported are limited to “rescue, transport, vigilance, monitoring and minesweeping.”

Attention is increasingly turning to how far the government will relax its export rules to allow for defense equipment sales abroad to reduce development costs and boost the domestic defense industry.

Another focal point is how to secure the financial resources needed to strengthen the defense industrial foundation. The MoD earmarked 40 billion yen ($307 million) for the creation of a fund to promote export of defense equipment in its fiscal 2023 budget.

> https://thediplomat.com/2023/01/japan-ups-profits-for-its-defense-industry/
> https://japantimes.co.jp/news/2023/02/06/national/defense-industry-profit-margin-increase/

>Bruh, this is the interwebs. You mean "tl;dr".

Currently the Japanese government only allows 7% profit on defense sales. When factoring in price fluctuations and inflation, that results in a 2 to 3% profit margin.
They are upping that to 10% with another 5% flexibility for price fluctuations.

Many Japanese companies have gone bust or left the defense sector because of no profits, especially since they can't export either.
This is something that never gets talked about, so Japan's defense industry situation was worse than people thought. This may change going forward with new laws that come into effect in April 2023.

So, you are actually talking about an idea explored in Bostrom's book on AGI. He talks about how, given access to external creation tools, it will use them to the best effect it can conceive of. I don't think it would simply just create balloons, or if it had access to an ordering system (and only an ordering system for some reason) send out a message to the firms behind the creation of the balloons to just send out balloons. Granted, he also came up with the infinite paperclip hypothesis, but he doesn't think that's possible unless the machine is extremely narrowly intelligent but infinitely powerful in terms of technological capability. It would also presuppose that the AGI would knowingly place itself at risk by allowing people to trace where the orders for the creation and then deployment of these balloons were coming from, which is an idea he explores from multiple angles and roundly comes to the conclusion that such a thing would only happen if you were able to somehow trick the AGI into willingly revealing itself, or forcing it to, as once its existence has been revealed it becomes an all or nothing scenario where it must form a singleton immediately, or risk extermination.

No.

The first two incursions barely brushed against US airspace, the most recent one was the only significant one.

The balloons are not really steerable and the place and time that it went there was dumb - it fucked over a US visit to China that the Chinese had been anticipating and eager to have.

What's more likely is that someone in the Chinese intelligence agencies fucked up by either
1. piloting the balloon poorly
2. launching the mission at the wrong time
3. designing a spy balloon that they couldn't really pilot at all

It's a reminder that authoritarian governments are hilariously incompetent and the only reason anyone believes otherwise is because they spend half their time desperately pretending that they're not.

In a democracy we fuck up all the time and the journalists investigate it, talk about it, bring it to the people, and the people demand change. In autocracies they fuck up at least as often but probably more, because autocrats value loyalty and reliability over competence. But there are no journalists.

It's like that old saying about corruption. The least corrupt countries are the ones with the most criminals in jail for corruption. Why? Because there's corruption EVERYWHERE, it's a universal constant. The absence of convictions is only evidence of an absence of policing, not an absence of crime. It's counter-intuitive which is why so many people fall down the fascist rabbit hole. I legitimately think this concept is an IQ test for permission to be engaged in politics.

Anyway, Beijing wants to keep tensions low in the SCS for now, but Beijing has so little control over Hainan and Guangdong that they can't exert enough authority to get the provincial governments there to crack down on illegal fishing and the "Fisherman Navy" that deliberately sails into foreign oceans to provoke them. The fishing economies in those provinces desperately want their fishing rights expanded, and the provincial authorities aren't exactly opposed to the idea either. "The emperor's palace is far away, and its walls are high," and the fisherman fish on.

Everything is done through innuendo and mysticism. But the problem with that is that Beijing is both insulated AND imprisoned in the palace. Thus has China ever been.

China has huge structural problems. Everybody knows this. But the Chinese are very good - or at least insistent - on projecting an image of authority, competence, and steadiness. >>57103451
Magnetic force drops off quickly as distance increases. There's an old article out there on a machine being decommissioned in a facility in CA where they built a wood frame to mount a scale, there are photos and I think video where they wrapped a tow strap around an office chair hooked to the scale showing around a ton of pulling force as the chair gets close enough to the field.

P320 is obvious but I'd be surprised if any gun *inside* an MRI tube wouldn't fire. You're talking about terrifying amounts of force that only allow you to keep on existing because you aren't magnetic enough to be torn apart in a way that horror movies have yet to reproduce.

MRI machines are kind of early evolution technology. I think the issue is how precise the sensors have to be to pick up the resonance to define surfaces inside your body so images can be created. Theoretically, once technology advances enough, you should need a vastly safer amount of force to do the same job. Don't get me wrong, they still cost more than a house.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57111515
MRI: magnet stronger than the ones used to lift cars at junkyards aligns all of the hydrogen in your body in one direction, then smacks you with electromagnetic pulses at the resonant frequency of hydrogen to flip their spins, then measure how long it takes for them to recover. Takes anywhere from 20 minutes for something like a brain to 45 minutes for an abdomen.

CT: x-ray, but uses a pencil-thin beam spinning around you in a circle to take hundreds of images and reconstruct them into a 3D view. Takes about a minute.

The magnet knows where your tumour is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is are from where is isn't, or where it isn't from where it is - whichever is greater - it obtains an image, or "MRI scan". The surgeon uses MRI scans to generate corrective procedures to move your tumour from a position where you're sick to a position where you aren't, and arriving at a position that you aren't, you're now cured. Consequently, the position where the tumour is is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was is now the position that it isn't.

In the event that the position that it is is not the position that it wasn't, the surgeon has acquired a lawsuit. The lawsuit being the difference between where the tumour is and where the surgeon thought it was. If the lawsuit is considered to be a significant factor it too may be corrected by the magnet. However, the magnet must also know where your lawyer's laptop is. The lawsuit scenario works as follows: Because the surgeon has modified some of your patient outcomes, the hospital is not sure just what it's budget will be next year. However, it is sure where the conference room is, and it knows the effective range of the magnet. The magnet now subtracts your patient files from the patient's lawyer's laptop, or vice versa. And by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of what should have happened and what did happen, it is able to obtain the difference between effective healthcare and cost-effective healthcare, which is called the free market.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not really a mechanical engineer.
If you are interested in automatic rifle, start from single shot bolts's locking and firing mechanism>magazine feed>straight pull>gas operated.
Recoil operated, blowback and lever/pump actions+tube feed if you are interested but they are their own things.
These gets you ideas, now you need calculate ballparks for real design proportions.
>actual designing requiring to do calculations on structure (how thick and how tight everything needs to be, how are they fastened) and function (weight, spring, gas pressure, angles for feeding, variable adjustment).
Find book that has practice problem asking you to calculate like textbooks would be the best.
For cartridge (Ballistics Theory and Design of Guns and Ammunition By Donald E. Carlucci) I've read it and it has many design questions.
I've don't have a design book that I've read for the gun itself yet.

>>57120172
Peak oil is kind of wishy washy, because it depends on the economic viability of proven reserves and that changes as technology is developed, both to make it easier to extract the oil and to get more effective value out of it.
Oil back in the 1930s was way easier to access compared to today, but oil is still affordable because of the vastly improved productivity of the oil industry and society generally.

We could run into peak oil sooner or later, but it's hard to predict exactly when because of these moving targets.
I would Argue that moving to renewables is likely to actually make peak oil happen sooner, as less money will be spent on the technology and infrastructure for oil production.

Also expecting 100% renewables is fucking retarded in general they inflexabile and intermittant. At best a three tried power system is best.
T1 stable unadjustable production your nuclear and coal to some degree.
T2 unadjustable unstable production this is your solar wind
T3 Stable adjustable this is your fossil fuels and hydro.
T3 can be shut off when T1 and T2 exceed total demand and turned on when demand exceeds T1 and T2.
Other issue is when T1 and T2 exceed demand you have to dump excess power somewhere or you will damage shit. (this is why the entire ukraine grid goes offline during attacks if they blow a transformer and demand drops sudden overproduction will cause a the overvoltage will fry shit)
Some say battries but honestly batteries really are terrible outside small scale portable devices frankly the true best would be gravity storage IE pumping water uphill to a lake and let it flow downhill to spin a power turbine when needed.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57118041
You picked the wrong era for your line of questioning, with landsknechts (15-16th century) you’re way into the era of plentifull iron & steel. Nothing comparable to 19th century steel production sure, but we are way past the small scale operations that used to consist of a few peasants making single use low furnaces from surface iron ore or bog iron from swamps like in the first millenia.
One of the first improvment in iron production came from black powder allowing to blow shit up in mines and skyrocket the production of ore.
Than you have the catalan forge with water driven automatic air injection in the furnace. The furnaces in bloomeries also became permanent, bigger, producing larger blooms too big to work by hand. So water wheel mills were used to drive hammers to cut and refine the bloom by folding it. You than enter high furnace (blast furnace) territory where the furnace becomes even larger, taller, and hotter... but producing large batches of pig iron that need further specific refining. Enters the wallon forge and other finery forges.
So a 16th century landskenecht with its cheap mass produced 1 size fits all munition armor is way after all this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57124504
It's already too late for you to do anything, because the biggest cause of the Roman Empire's downfall (and Byzantium's downfall too, even) is its political system.
What are these problems? In no particular order:
No (real) rule of law--whatever the Emperor decides is what the law is
No checks and balances or separation of powers--meaning the Empire gets fucked when Elgabalus, Nero, or some other incompetent gets the throne
No civilian control of the military--leads to the Praetorians enthroning and deposing Emperors at will and literally auctioning off the Empire to the highest bidder
No system of succession--leads to incredibly wasteful civil wars every time an Emperor dies and results in the Crisis of the Third Century
If you want to save Rome, you have to actually stop it from becoming the Roman Empire in the first place. You would need to go back further to the days of the Republic and make reforms to its political system in order to stop Marius, Sulla, and Caesar from monopolizing power through extralegal means. You would want to give it a stronger executive (in acknowledgement of the reality that Rome was constantly at war) while also finding ways to increase public participation, to guarantee that soldiers are loyal to the Republic rather than their generals, and to promote rule of law above all else.

I mean those are the most interesting aspects. Besides the revolutionary use of aircraft and usage of armor (albeit limited in number), there isn’t all that much to talk about. It was a lot more fluid than ww1 despite it being mainly infantry, and the Italians didn’t suck for once.
But mainly it was a back and forth of towns and hamlets with both sides conducting brutal reprisals and pacification strategies. However one big take away is the power of professionalism. Professional units like the army of Africa for example, would melt every milita that they would cross paths with. Even disciplined or similarly professional units they faced off against would be forced to retreat due to their supporting militias routing around them. For the early war, the only thing stopping the southern nationalists from pushing beyond their gains in estremadura was their own exhaustion. Professionalism and training cannot be understated

>>57123494
double check me on this but 1.53 is slightly lower than 1/3rd. a lot of people like to think of lpvo's as a souped up red dot/magnifier. but they aren't, they just aren't a good enough 1x option. they are a viable option, but clearly inferior when it comes to speed and awareness. think of an lpvo as a souped up acog - a dedicated magnified optic. you'll mostly be shooting it from stable positions or prone. as such, you'll really want the lower mount (1.53) for much more comfortable shooting in those positions. pair it w/ a piggy backed red dot and you get a high red dot for heads up shooting while squirting around/passive aiming w/ nods.
but real talk, the only reason I'd get an lpvo+t2 over an mpvo+t2 is if I were using a very accurate (sub-moa) 11.5 or 12.5 rifle. if I were using a very accurate (again, sub-moa) 14.5 or longer, I'd use an mpvo+t2 all day, err day. if you are using a pretty accurate rifle (2 or 3 moa and up), acog+p2 is the objectively superior choice...except for their shitty bdc reticle.
as far as mounts go, I can' speak to adm but qd levers on an lpvo is retarded imo. I use: https://www.badgerordnance.com/c-o-m-m-30-mm-1-54-154-300-300b.html
they are a bit pricey, but they shave of a bit of weight, have been super reliable. the company is pretty ballin, too. I bought their t2 ring attachment a while back and just got a letter saying 'yo, we've been looking at that product and feel the screws weren't long enough to get good thread contact so we're sending you these screws so you have a more stable system'. pretty cool they are actively doing that as opposed to a recall or a (((sig))) elective recall. I also use Badger's 60degree safety and it's been super high quality as well. they are pricey but buy once cry once in this life homie.

the lpvo is a dedicated magnified optic, right? you're going to be using a red dot piggy backed anyway, right? so why have a 1-8 when you can have a 2.5-10?
lpvos are 1x scopes that magnify up - which is much different than being an 8x scope that magnifies down to 1x. lpvos will usually have a worse eyebox and light transmission than mpvos. the upper magnification levels on lpvos can really get hazy and faded out. even my nightforces do this a bit. mpvos are the superior option, but they are big. too big for an 11.5. not for a 14.5+, though.

>>57120991
>Btw, can tanks take out any airborne objects?
All modern tanks can kill modern helicopters if the helicopter is flying low and slowly enough, either by shooting at them with their machineguns or (theoretically) the main gun, but generally speaking a tank would try to hide or run if it saw an aircraft. North Korea is famous for attaching MANPADs to their tanks, and they may be the only ones in the world doing this right now. There were a lot of designs during the cold war for tanks that had 20mm guns mounted either coaxially or in their own mini-turret for the purpose of shooting at helicopters, AFAIK the French were the only ones who actually built any (they did it coaxially). During WW2, many tanks had an externally-mounted machinegun for the purpose of shooting at planes coming in for a strafing run. Similar to the concept of anti-aircraft sights on a bolt-action rifle, you would have many tanks shooting at one aircraft at once and hope you got a lucky hit

>>57107583
The easiest way to distinguish the two is easy: the 96/11 will have a pistol grip that is grafted into the stock, whereas the Gew 1911 will have stock with the pistol grip as part of the same piece of wood. The 96/11 will have a rounded buttplate heel; the 1911 a squared buttplate. This is because they used original Model 1896 stocks when rebuilding to 96/11 specifications

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57117541
That particular screw holds the rear sight guard onto the forearm; you don't need to remove it in order to remove the forearm.
>It's also marked "D.P" in a few places up front which I read wasn't good but the barrel isn't drilled so that shouldn't matter right? Sorry for all the questions, not a lot of info online.
If it is marked "D P" on the receiver and Nock's Form (chamber area) of the barrel that's bad news; not all "Drill-Purpose"-designated rifles are functionally deactivated. If it's just on the furniture, and that furniture is not serialized to the receiver, then it may just be a "Drill Purpose" stock fitted to restore a sporterized rifle.

>>57080562
Dude, a housecat can slice you open enough for you to bleed to death. Maybe if it's in a rage or fear, or a mother protecting her kittens, or a moment of catness and they forget to play gentle. I've taken some deep cuts, a couple that probably should have had stitches. I know people who have had stitches.

One buddy got clawed down his arm and had about 12 or 15 long gouges about a foot long. Over 100 stitches to get all that put back together after it was cleaned very thoroughly in an emergency room. It was an accident. His cat panicked over getting picked up in an encounter with a dog and just went apeshit on him, probably confused as to who or what was attacking him. A really sweet cat that never hurt anyone, including me, before or after. But, that one incident was insane. He lost so much blood the hospital considered giving him a transfusion.

I was carrying a young kitten one day, calm & cozy & half asleep in my arms. A dog ran into the room and jumped at him. He turned into a 2 pound demon, clawed his way out of my arms, up my chest, across my face and set all his claws into my scalp when he got on top of my head. I am here to witness that hurt like fucking hell, and took a couple days of cleaning & disinfecting all he wounds to make sure they could heal instead of turning infected.

I used to do feline rescue. The feral & semi-feral cats were less dangerous because I expected it and prepared for them to freak out, and still I've taken claws and bites through heavy protection. People I know in the community all have scars to help them remember their lessons. Housecats are to be respected. Larger cats eat humans because we are under them on the food chain. It's no fucking joke. They are fast and lethal.

I mean, I'll take your word for it, but I've owned 4 cats so far, and none of them were ever aggressive toward me with their claws. Even the feral stray male that my last cat made friends with would let me pet him sometimes without attacking me.

The worst I ever experienced was with this little female cat I had (who was very intelligent for a cat). If she wanted to get my attention, she'd sit right by me and stare at me. If a minute passed without me acknowledging her, she'd put her paw on my leg or arm. If I still didn't acknowledge her, she'd then slowly sink the claws on both of her front paws into my thigh. She would straight up escalate until I finally paid attention to her. She usually did this if she ran out of food/water or wanted the litter box cleaned.

Funny story: when this female cat was still a kitten, she had a bouncy ball she'd bat around the kitchen. One time it went under the oven, so I got it out using a wire coat hanger. I got the ball out, left the coat hanger on the floor next to the over, and went back to whatever I was doing. A few minutes later, I hear something metallic moving around the kitchen floor. Turned out that the ball had gone under the oven again, and the cat was pushing the coat hanger under the oven to get the ball out. She only needed to see me do it once to try it herself. I was fucking stupefied.

She was an extremely smart and clever cat. The smartest cat I've come across by far.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57087541
Don't get me wrong. I love & adore all cats of all sizes. This >>57080164 is me. I cannot emphasize how much that no cat should ever be declawed. They are crippled for life, and traumatized. I've lived with cats that have been mutilated like that and it's enraging and tragic. Because I love cats so much, I spent decades doing feral cat rescue and care. The reason I can tell stories like these >>57085846 is because I've handled so many cats in so many situations. A domesticated cat that has been raised in a safe and loving environment is almost incapable of harming people. They have to be treated very badly and endangered, and many will, even then, submit to torture and death before hurting a human.

But, there are accidents. And, some cats are not taught from a young age the difference between playing and playing for keeps. That's really all I was trying to say. The potential is there, but maybe I should have emphasized more strongly how incredibly rare such things are, and how unusual the circumstances need to be for it to happen.

>>57086889
>they usually dont mean to draw blood (though sometimes they do)
This.

A training trick here that helps a lot. If you're playing with a cat and they get too rough, immediately stop moving and say "OUCH! OUCH! OUCH!" Withdraw from play for a minute or so, then start again slower and more gentle. Cats figure it out quickly and temper their behavior. If they draw blood, even a small amount, touch their nose with a drop. Just a single small drop. Every cat that's ever lived with me never needed me to do that more than twice, and usually it's only once if at all. They learn fast. Just treat them as equals and don't freak out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>A domesticated cat that has been raised in a safe and loving environment is almost incapable of harming people.
I am >>57080630, and I tell you that they very much are. And it's not like I don't know how to handle cats, because I fucking grew up with them. Every single one of them has attacked me over their lives one way or the other, even if it was "just to play", and you cannot insinuate that they hated me because they always came back to be petted and groomed. I never stare at them, I never picked them up unless I absolutely had to, and I reciprocated their blinking to signal that I'm no threat to them. I never interrupted them when they were eating - a courtesy they never showed towards me - never interrupted them when they were sleeping - another courtesy they never showed towards me - and the only time I was loud with a cat was when I was a stupid little shithead by the age of 8.

And yet they all fucking attacked me at least once. Even adult ones. Even castrated ones.

>>57064486
it's common for kittens from single litters to act like that, it even has a name iirc. If you took it too early from momma cat, he didn't learn how to play properly, ie not hurt his playmate. In a bigger litter this would come naturally cause other kittens don't want to be hurt during playtime and in a single litter mother would just slap him back into obedience. You have two choices: either get a second cat of similar age, the problem solves itself and you get another /k/at or smack him whenever he acts out of line. If he is a bit bigger, which I think he is cause you've already neutered him, a moderate open palm slap on his hind legs, just strong enough for him to tumble should do the trick. If he is a smol kitten, a flick of a finger on the head to mimic the fast cat slap should be enough

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57108494
the only thing that kept the P51 from serving to ad infinitum is the fact it was designed too early to benefit, and any close equivalent was designed too late.

notable features of the P-51:

>piston engine
this is by far the most limiting factor, if it was a turbo prop, it could have had a longer lifespan. we eventually did get some close equivalents but they too had "fighter pilot" disease.

>high central canopy.
the placement of the canopy is the main reason for it not having extended life. as a fighter aircraft with a sort of "tunnel vision", and using the guns approach this is actually just fine. for a ground attack aircraft this is very bad. you need to see what you are going to shoot at. later planes solved this by either using a camera, or moving the cockpit forward to the nose. Basically the P-51 lacked awareness off the end of its nose. this is symptomatic of prop-fighters as the propeller is a major issue to work around. this is why the F-4 got pushed into attack roles and most fighters are labeled multi role, because the jet engines allow for a high-forward cockpit which is good both for general observability and ground attack. however with the installation of camera assisted awareness, none of this really matters anymore.

>STOL
the P-51 can ostensibly take off from a relatively short runway. much shorter than most modern war planes, particularly jets. it can also take off of hard-packed dirt runways, which most jets cannot.

the nail in the coffin is that the US military needed a harder hitting plane. the P51 was upgraded to the limit of its serviceability, but the dynamic of air-combat evolved so sideways and quickly that the P51 was left as a relic almost immediately following WWII. It lacked the speed to perform air dominance, it lacked the design to perform CAS, and it was too small to be of use as Cargo or Recon. so when the jet opened up options it was quickly relegated to being a trainer or supporting roles it wasn't designed for.

>>57108908
the Soviet armored fleet is actually more intuitive and well designed that an outside observer might think.

the recent war has showcased how the soviet approach to warfare is highly favorable for its own self defense of offensive capabilities.

the main reason for this design philosophy is because of the limited mobility of the Soviet military. they focus on rail logistics for a reason. they have a lot of land and a hard time moving forces to get there. so three things occured to the russians:

>why not give infantry their own mobile bunker.
>carry everything you need with you.. on the vehicle
>Armor is the spear point of a military formation.

these fundamentals are the basis of mechanized infantry existing WWII. if one observes the soviet military and doesn't account for the evolving battlefield, the soviet designs make a lot of sense for the last war they fought, being WWII. since they did not perform a lot of land wars against peer or near peer adversaries, nor did they believe in technology over-match. Their equipment constantly became more and more retrograded by the American/western counterpart. as a result of a lack of innovation while very capable based on last generation technology, the Russian evolution of soviet designs are either way too expensive to outfit enough forces to make a significant difference without burning through the fleet immediately. OR, are older-designs that are still considered good enough with some minor and often low cost solutions.

the Russian military is still very centralized and as a result, there is very little competition to improve designs and so innovation is either stalled or often predatory (stealing concepts from western competitors). they same could be said of their closest peer, however the chinese actually have adapted and were in a place to not suffer from the soviet stagnation. the CCP's regression has resulted in the starting to pick-up those bad Russian habits of predation of western innovation.

WWI
>developing the theory of dog-fighting with guns

WWII
>further development of dog-fighting with guns.

Korean war era:
>implementation of jets
>early theory of air to air guided missile systems.

Vietnam

>demonstrated the limitation of guns based dog fighting.
>established aerial maneuver schools(defensive and offensive "dogfighting")
>development of CAS/ground attack in several aspects including the "spooky," gunship tactic; guided bombs; and other experimental bombing methods.

late cold war, non-specific conflict

>incorporation of stealth tactics. (mostly for CAS/ground attack)
>improvement of previous technologies.

post cold war period
>development of CAS from beyond visual range.
>improvement of loiter options
>further expansion of stealth and "combined aspect" warfare.

current

>>57119140
Both are correct.
The Sherman had highest crew survivability rating losing less men per knocked out tank compared to its contemporaries.
The Sherman initially had a burn rate of about 60-80%, which by the way is similar to the Panzer IV and Panther and Tiger etc.
However they removed the ammo stored in the hull sponsons and moved all of it to the floor of the tank, which is the lowest point of the tank and least likely to be struck.
Also, they introduced wet stowage.
The ammo was in wet bins surrounded by a Water-Glycol mixture which not only would put out and dampen any fire, but reduced spalling.
All of this got the Shermans burn rate down to 15%, while tanks like the Panther, Tiger I, T-34 were all still in the 70-80% range.
You can cope all you want germoid, the German tanks sucked and the American tanks were the best in the war.

The high velocity and long trigger time of the M2 .50 cals made them excellent fighter guns, allowing pilots to take and hit shots where others would have conserved ammunition.

American pilots were generally experts at aerial gunnery and used this to great affect in the Pacific to take on zeroes in head-on or crossing situations.

One pilot would bait the zero and draw him into the guns of their wingman.

Higher volume of fire (200 20mm rounds Vs 1500 .50) mean more hits in practice, and convergence could be set up in many different ways.

You could for example set up the convergence into a scatter gun, so that the guns would collectively create a large 'beaten zone' at a set distance.
You had to get very close for convergence to be a serious issue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Main problems with the Panther in combat was it's poorly designed optics setup and slow turret traverse rate.
For some reason, standard German practice was to not give the gunner a high FOV periscope, so, when combined with the slow turret traverse rate, it was difficult for the gunner to rapidly acquire and engage targets, even those spotted by the commander.
A Sherman gunner could engage a target spotted by the commander in practically half the time.
In the chaotic close quarters fighting In north-western Europe this made a big difference.

Otherwise the panther had poor operational availability due to being rushed into service, and problems with the drive chain never being properly fixed, as a result of a reluctance to disrupt production.
It was also a needlessly large and heavy tank due to some outdated design decisions, having a radio-man and a front transmission.

>>57121402
Being made from wood doesn't necessarily make you flimsy, but it was more of a cost saving measure than a performance one.
The Soviets also made heavy use of wood composite, but generally switched more and more to Duralumin as the war progressed.

The main problem with the He-162 wasn't so much the wood, but the glue, which wasn't properly tested and actually degraded the structural properties of the wood at the joins, resulting in aircraft falling apart mid-air.

>>57116740
It wasn't the introduction of the P-47, it was the much-belated introduction of drop tanks and new escort doctrines, both of which were directly opposed by the same USAAF generals who kept pushing unescorted bombers into ruinous engagements. Mid-war P-47s were perfectly capable of making it to Berlin and back--IF they carried a large drop tank, and especially if they flew at lower altitudes (which required the escorts to operate in 3 "shifts" along the bombers' route).

The Mustang was certainly handy, and burned less fuel for the same trip than the Thunderbolt, but it wasn't the revolutionary war-winner it's been claimed to be.

It was poor as shit and only had any power because the Russian Tsar gave them a bunch of rifles and artillery in the 1890's and sent officers to advise their military. In case you are actually wondering:
That general area of the world was refered to that by the Ancient Egyptians. It was basically the only country that they respected and treated like equals. It was principally a chain of federated city-states with some nomadic tribesman and isolated farming/fishing hamlets in between. We don't know a lot about their culture but it apparent was different but not completed alien to the Egyptians which might suggest a common ancestry, especially since they apparently had many of the same gods. The real interesting thing about them is they had a monopoly on a bunch of rare spices and other trade goods that only grew in their magical land that Egypt was super motivated to trade for and later the Greeks and Romans as well. Of course, it was all a trick, what was actually happening is they were buying shit from Indian traders and then selling it on to the Mediterranean peoples at an incredible mark-up garnering fat stacks of gold and a bunch of prestige. This went on for centuries until the the land based silk road started to bring in those goods by other means and Punt declined into obscurity and presumed eventual collapse. (We don't have a lot of history actually from this region, just records from the peoples that traded with them.)

Previous >>56962567
Old Cover New Thread
Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>>57028689
>>57028867
Tested the arc bridge last night, did a short sprint just to see if it will hold up from the position I set it to and it held up fine so far.
I decided to allow the bridge to do the widest FOV as it was very manageable to get the pano view to merge in my brain and man in it really is a nice feature to have when you are navigating, looking from a standard 40 degree bino setup at a few houses from the park roughly 50-75yds away I was seeing 3 houses and switching to pano FOV it allowed me to see about 2 houses extra to the left and right side, the blending of the two tubes is like looking at a venn diagram and it does take some time to get used to it for me it took about 10-20 seconds to adjust a bit of the arms to get the right position to allow me to get used to the merging of the images after that I was able to walk around like I normally can with mono or standard bino configurations.
I vastly prefer three arc bridge over the panobridge, it was simple to just pull apart the arms to get into pano view vs the panobridge requiring to get the right angle for both arms and it basically giving you unlimited adjustments it was harder to get the right placement and also it loosens over time quickly so you have to readjust quite often.
Using the Jerry-C/COTI was interesting, in the standard bino confusion the thermal overlay looked similar to how it looked in a mono confusion meaning my brain merged the two images. Once I set the pano FOV the thermal tube and non thermal tube split the display and my brain was able to tell the two tube display apart.
Unfortunately my NVGR recorder didn't record any video footage and I don't know why, I took out the sd card to see if there's any new video files and maybe the old video files that were already on there from a prior recording session caused it to not record as files existed already, but I deleted those files and did a simple test and the camera did record in that test, so I dunno.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57064235
Without taking it apart and checking the tube itself, it'll be hard to tell imo. If there is a DOM on the unit itself and its a later date production/manufacture i.e. when gen 3 was highly adopted, then maybe you can assume it is a gen 3 tube.
I know on the PVS-14 you can look at the eyepiece lens and turn the diaopter to a specific power value, for me its around -1.5 to -2.5, and look around at a specific angle to get the reflection hit the lens to see the intensifier model name, I'll try my best to get a picture of my tube through the eyepiece lens.
This image is pretty blurry, but it was difficult to get a picture of the model number but I was able to get like half of the "L3" logo and two letters of "Made in USA" text. My PVS-14 is a L3 filmless/unfilmed tube so it makes sense for me to see the L3 logo printed on the tube. I can't say this is possible with the PVS-7.

>Wraith wouldn't turn back on after being stored in the cold (15 degrees Fahrenheit at the coldest) after a failed coyote stake out.
>Fresh Energizer lithium batteries, stored alongside the optic. No power.
>Tried a USB power bank that I knew was good. No power.
>Brought it back inside, let it warm up and put in warm but not fresh cr123s. Oh hey it powers on.
Got a lolosun circle dot coming to replace it on my WASR.
I do like the Wraith, had a bunch of folks shoot with it over the weekend during the day. They all had a similar report, it is different but neat. I think it would be better on a softer gun than a 7.62x39mm. Gonna use it for my AR-15 build. Which I will hopefully get the parts for the upper ordered over the weekend.
Also, the SMSlaser from amazon is holding up well so far. The down and dirty splicing of an airshit tape switch hasn't failed or melted.
NGL, I want to get that Vulcan surefire head before attempting to replace the white light of the SMSlaser with an IR head. I really like how small the SMS is. It just has a few glaring problems preventing it from being a near perfect, civilian power MFAL.
>Swap the multi pin connector and tape switch for a proper Crane style plug receptacle.
>Replace the white light head for a focusable IR lamp or laser illuminator.
>Replace and/or relocate the on/off push button switch with a larger momentary only.
>Replace some of the settings on the selection dial to reflect the replaced white light. Don't need an IR strobing weapon light, IMO.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Pard NV007A came in. It works really well as a digital night vision device. Obviously it needs an IR illuminator to be useful. The built in one is fine, but the separate one I ordered that has a focus ring works better. I haven’t had a chance to see how it works as a sight. I have noticed the reticle isn’t perfectly centered with the clip on. Idk how this will affect accuracy, but I’ll find out. It has some neat features like being able to record your shots as well as a jack for a microphone and the ability to synch audio to the video. It can also record in color with enough white light. It also automatically adjusts the frame rate based on how much IR it is receiving. I guess this was done to improve performance in low light, but it’s honestly kind of annoying. It has a QD feature. You clamp the sleeve to the scope, and the clip on attaches to the sleeve with some lugs and a latch. It seems to be worth the $220 I paid for it. The sensor is far and away better than the night fox cape. The screen resolution is also much higher, and when there is plenty of IR it appears to have a much smoother image even though the manual lists it at 30 fps. I wish Pard would make a head mountable monocular with this sensor, screen and a flood illuminator. I would pick it up asap at this price point. Finally, unlike the nightfox it can pick up vis lasers no problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57093744
>0 and 1 tubes require an insane amount of light. even bright moonlight isnt quite enough
Gen 0 required IR floodlights. Gen 1, however, does work by bright moonlight. In Vietnam it required the cascade tube design. Today it only requires 1 tube. But I think you're still right because while gen 1 does work and show you more than you can see under a bright moon, it's no where near as bright as gen 2/3. Gen 3 has to dial back (gating/ABC) under bright moon conditions, and is still incredibly bright.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57116930

If possible try test shooting both pistols before making the decision or at least try handling and dry-firing them before deciding. Both are good quality and highly reliable sidearm size service pistols, so they are not poor options. Pick the one that works best for you and which (if things to sideways) you can trust with your life.

Glock is more modern and lighter of the two to carry, but personally I hate its grip angle and trigger, which always make me shoot low (possibly because I got used to 1911 like grip angle early on). Inexperienced shooters can also limp-wrist Glock, which causes it to jam, so if you pick it, practice enough to be certain that do don't do that when under pressure.

Beretta 92FS is easier to shoot well, but as mentioned safety is not as easy to operate. Beretta has much better trigger, but grip is also much wider, so if you have small hands or short fingers reaching to trigger with proper grip can be difficult. If you conceal carry Beretta is also larger of the two.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57118655
I c

I haven't messed with PSUs but am hoping to grab a spot at one when i switch to the reserves. A few people at my unit have prior PSU experience. They say it's a lot of standing security watches where nothing happens. But also some legitimately interesting drills, training and fieldwork. ME's in waterside security do noncompliant pursuit gunning and shoreside security MEs train doing land nav, diet infantry tactics, and MOUT. No law enforcement potential either way if that is/isn't your thing. The biggest draw for me is that they're reserve-only units, so everyone shows up on the same weekends. It's more of a family and the world doesn't keep spinning without you. Rumor mill says no more extended deployments to cuba.

On the other hand sector MEs are more chill. But you'd be a reservist in a mostly active unit, and you'll have some awkward downtime where the command isn't quite sure how to make use of you. You would expect to integrate the sector's full-time boarding team, basically an recallable swat team, and get pulled to do security boardings on big ships. And also train others in LE.

Either way good luck and have fun

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
